qas.question: What facilitated the rise of Sumerian cities?
How were trade goods transported in southern Mesopotamia?

answers.text: transported along the canals and rivers

qas.question: How many people lived in the cities?
During which period did Sumerian cities begin using slave labor?
What have been found as far east as central Iran?
What period ranged from the 41st to the 29th century BC?
What was transported along the rovers and canals of northern Mesopotamia?
Who employed many laborers in the cities?
When did Sumerians stop using slave labor?

context: By the time of the <b5_0>Uruk period<b5_0/> (c. 4100–2900 BC calibrated), the volume of <a0_0>trade <b6_0>goods<b6_0/><a0_0/> <a1_0>transported along the canals and rivers<a1_0/> of southern Mesopotamia facilitated the rise of many large, stratified, temple-centered cities (with populations of <a2_0>over 10,000<a2_0/> people) where <b7_0>centralized administrations<b7_0/> employed specialized workers. It is fairly certain that it was during the <a3_0><b8_0>Uruk<a3_0/> period<b8_0/> that Sumerian cities began to make use of slave labor captured from the hill country, and there is ample evidence for captured slaves as workers in the earliest texts. <a4_0>Artifacts<a4_0/>, and even colonies of this Uruk civilization have been found over a wide area—from the Taurus Mountains in Turkey, to the Mediterranean Sea in the west, and as far east as central Iran.
